title: Planet of the Rani
author: Marc Platt
filename: 205 - Planet of the Rani - Marc Platt_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
1. INT. AUDIENCE CHAMBER — RANI’S PALACE — MIASIMIA GORIA
FX: BALINESE STYLE MUSIC, GENTLE, EXOTIC GAMELANS AND GONGS,
INTRODUCES US TO THE PLANET MIASIMIA GORIA.
IS DISRUPTED BY A DISTANT EXPLOSION AND GUNSHOTS. A DOOR OPENS. CHOWDRAS ENTERS.
Degoor? You’re still here?
As you can see, yes.
I thought you’d run with the others. You’ll never get away now. The space-field’s burning.
The last shuttles left long ago. I saw no reason to desert the palace.
That makes you the last out-worlder on Miasimia Goria.
Perhaps. Is that your nightshirt, Chowdras?
The madness started in the early hours. We’1ll never sleep again — even those of us spared the Great Experiment.
You are exempt because of your duties.
It’s a curse. I wish I had the madness too. Oblivion would be better than watching the world destroy itself.
FX: ANOTHER DISTANT EXPLOSION.
The rebels are coming closer, yes.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page
They’re not rebels. They’ve lost their reason. And I can’t believe She didn’t know this might happen!
The Experiment is not over yet.
Really? Even though She’s fled?
She went to find a solution! She will return, believe me.
Then she’d better hurry. No-one sleeps. No-one remembers how.
They’1l soon all be dead.
Apart from one. How is little Kahnu?
FX: CHOWDRAS OPENS A DOOR. CONTINUES INTO:
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 4
2. INT. KAHNU’S NURSERY [CONTINUOUS]
FX: TINY BELLS TINKLE.
DEGOOR AND CHOWDRAS ENTER.
He’s not strong... but he was always her favourite. Her little princeling. Oh, yes.
FX: A CHILD CHUCKLES. HE PLAYS WITH THE BELLS.
One year old and brighter than youngsters three times his age.
And his sleep?
He never sleeps — not that it seems to worry him.
Why was he left unguarded?
There are no guards left! The rest of us are exhausted. We’ve tried putting him on a monitor.. but he pulls it apart. He’s fascinated by its workings.
Keep Kahnu alive, Chowdras. Forget the rest. Our beloved Rani, a thousand blessings upon her, will not reward total failure when she returns. At least offer her one success.
She scares you as much as the rest of us. Hasn’t she done enough damage?
She is our ruler. Remember that. And she will return.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 5
3. INT. TECCAURORA HIGH SECURITY PENITENTIARY —
RECEPTION/LIFT/CELL
FX: HIGH TECH AND ECHOEY. METAL GRILLE SLIDES BACK.
Gurney coming through.
FX: A GURNEY TRUNDLES FORWARD AND STOPS.
Thank you, guard seven-two-one. All checks finalised. Identity confirmed. Prisoner Indigo zero one eleven three six sigma received. — Close the gate, will you?
Sir.
FX: GRILLE SLIDES SHUT WITH A CLANG.
Welcome to Teccaurora High Security Penitentiary, madam. I am the Governor. I trust your expedition from court wasn’t too uncomfortable? (NO ANSWER) Right. Bring her down, seven-two- one.
FX: ANOTHER DOOR SLIDES OPEN. THE GURNEY ADVANCES INTO A LIFT.
THE GOVERNOR AND THE GUARD WALK IN WITH IT. THE LIFT DOOR CLOSES. THE LIFT DESCENDS. FLOORS THRUM PAST.

Your cell is in Sigma block. That’s eighteen levels down. Not much of a view, I’m afraid. (SILENCE) Well... the first few days here are always a shock, but we pride ourselves on our facilities. Most inmates find them stimulating. We’ve an extensive library with particular reference to the arts and science — chemistry is your field, I understand. I’m sure you’1ll find much to engage you.
FX: LIFT STOPS. DOORS OPEN. GURNEY, GOVERNOR AND GUARD ADVANCE.
From now on, you’ll be addressed by your registration number. Your previous identity no longer exists. Everyone is equal
here.
FX: GURNEY STOPS. DOOR OPENS.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 6
And this is it. Your home for the duration of your sentence... (FX: HE CONSULTS A PAPER) .. which in your case, amounts to the rest of your life. — Right. House rules are listed on your
facility console. Lights and heating are controlled from outside. The bathroom’s through there. Any questions? (SILENCE) No? Very good. Then I’11l leave you to settle in.
How many others?
Hmm?
How many other prisoners?
We hold nine hundred high security prisoners. Despite our endeavours, there’s always a stream of offenders to keep us busy. But don’t worry. You won’t be ignored. Your rehabilitation starts here.
How reassuring... to know that I am not alone.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 7
4. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: TARDIS HUM. CONSTANCE CHECKING THE DOCTOR’S EMAILS — INBOX
CHIMES.
Oh, for goodness’ sake, Doctor. How many of these electronic ‘letters’ have gone unanswered?
I wouldn’t worry, ‘Mrs Clarke’. Most are unsolicited interplanetary spam. Easily deleted.
Spam? That’s what the GIs brought with them. — I mean, look at all these. What you need is a personal secretary.
Are you applying for the job?
No, I am not.
Ah... well... I’m delighted to hear it.
BEAT.
Even So...
Yes!
BEAT.
Oh, never mind.
All relevant correspondence will be answered in good time. The tiresome strictures of a linear existence are rendered irrelevant when you travel in time. It’s all relative, you know.
Yes, Doctor.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 8
And ‘missing the post’ becomes a thing of the past. — Ooh, look. Apparently my systems are running too slowly.
So we can lose that for a start off.
FX: BLIPS CONSOLE.
The ‘Tecc-au-rora High Security Penitentiary’? What’s that? Sounds like a prison.
Oh, just administrative. Best ignored.
But it’s marked URGENT.
Nothing to worry about.
FX: BLIPS CONSOLE.
There are more of them. Plenty more. All from the same place.
Excuse me. Whose private mailbox is this?
But it looks important. (FX: BLIPS CONSOLE.) “Dear Doctor...”
No!
“We have made numerous attempts to request your attendance at a parole hearing for the prisoner...”
Parole!
“..cthe prisoner Ushas of Mee-a-simia Goria.”
My — asimia.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 9
Someone you know?
Maybe. (GIVES IN) An old opponent of mine, since you’re asking.
And he’s in prison?
The Rani is a She.
Oh.
And not the first of my academic contemporaries to land up behind bars either. We were a vintage year.
You should have met mine at Somerville.
Really?
So what did ‘the Rani’ do?
How long have you got? Her list of crimes is extensive to say the least. A brilliant mind corrupted... but ‘parole’ is not what I’d expected. Not ever.
Then surely that’s even more reason to attend the hearing.
You can be quite persistent when you want to be, can’t you, Mrs Clarke?
Only trying to be helpful.
(SIGHS) Oh, alright. My guilt is needled quite enough. (FX: HE
BLIPPING IN COORDINATES) Prison visiting was not on my immediate agenda, but anything for a bit of peace and quiet.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 10
5. INT. TECCAURORA — CONTROL OFFICE
MUSIC: GIVES A SENSE OF A MAJOR TECHNICAL PROJECT IN FULL FLOW.
FX: HUM OF COMPUTER SECURITY SYSTEM.
Sigma block. We’re waiting on your connection.
(ON COMM) Problems with the restraint webbing, sir.
Well, get on with it. The Governor’s waiting.
(COMM) Sir.
All blocks. Standby to commence the feed regime in ten params.
FX: CROSS TO:
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 11
6. INT. TECCAURORA — SIGMA BLOCK — CORRIDOR [CONTINUOUS]
(TANNOY — SLIGHT ECHO) Check all monitors and input feed clearance. Repeat — feed regime commences in ten params.
FX: AFTER A COUPLE OF BEATS THE TARDIS GROANS AND WHEEZES ITS
INTO REALITY. DOOR OPENS.
(EMERGING) No, no. I always bypass reception desks. What’s the point of a surprise inspection if your arrival is anticipated?
(FOLLOWING) Poo-er! They could open a few windows round here.

You’1l be lucky. (FX: CLOSES TARDIS DOOR) This Penitentiary is Situated at the heart of the Teccaurora Diamond Belt. They built the whole complex inside an asteroid. It’s well-nigh escape proof... allegedly.
It didn’t stop us getting in.
Exactly my point. Standards are obviously slipping.
FX: HE SLIDES OPEN A DOOR. THEY STEP THROUGH.
These cells have held some notorious criminals in their time. The Immazma Smythe gang, Poldrini the Cold...
They sound more like variety acts.
That’s truer than you think. I wonder which block they’ve housed the Rani in...
We might have to check each of the cells in turn. They appear to have peepholes of sorts.
Careful.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 12
FX: CONSTANCE SLIDES OPEN A VIEWING PANEL.
Oh! The prisoner’s strapped up to a machine.
Can I see? Oh, yes. Probably some sort of medication.
FX: CONSTANCE WALKS TO THE NEXT DOOR AND SLIDES OPEN ANOTHER
PANEL. THE DOCTOR FOLLOWS.
This one’s the same.
Now that looks more like enforced sedation... which I understood was banned in this establishment. Criminals have rights, too. If I’d known I’d have thought twice about having the Rani sent here.
You had her imprisoned?
I had a little influence over the matter. But she’d left the authorities no choice. She always was her own worst enemy.
She really is that bad?
Regrettably, yes. (FX: HE SLIDES OPEN ANOTHER PANEL) Oh, and here’s another. — Have they knocked out the entire prison
population? Where are all the staff?
Doctor? Is that a film camera, up there? Are we being watched?
Very probably. (ALOUD) Excuse me. Hello! This is the Doctor. You requested my attendance... [at a hearing].
(DISTANT)
LAUGHING ALOUD
What was that?
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 13
FX: DOCTOR SETS OFF AT A PACE.
Someone’s enjoying themselves.
(DISTANT) Doctor! (SCREAMS )
Along here!
Doctor, wait! Whoever that was, she was calling your name!
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 14
7. INT. PAZMI’S CELL
LYING IN BED, RAMBLING DELIRIOUSLY AS SHE SENSES THINGS
THEY HAPPEN.
FX: HER LIFE SUPPORT UNIT PULSING.
You’re taking your time. (LAUGHING) But it’1l never work. Oh. Oh, he’s here.
FX: VIEW PANEL IN THE DOOR SLIDES BACK.
(OUTSIDE, THROUGH OPENING) Hello? Were you calling me?
Must be eight params to go by now.
(OUTSIDE) She’s connected up like the others.
(OUTSIDE) Hello? Can we help?
Who are you? (IMITATING THE DOCTOR) “I’m the Doctor. I always cut things fine.”
(OUTSIDE) I’m the... ah.. You were expecting me?
(OUTSIDE) Is she delirious?
(OUTSIDE) Very possibly.
(FORESEEING) The door’s open.
(OUTSIDE) Hang on while I circumvent the door lock.
I said “the door’s open.”
(OUTSIDE)
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB)
What?
(FORESEEING) “Try the handle.”
(OUTSIDE) It’s open. Try the...
(OUTSIDE) Try the handle. Yes, I know!
LAUGHS
FX: THEY OPEN THE DOOR AND ENTER.
You took your time.
Page 15
I’m the Doctor. Cutting things fine is an occupational hazard.
(IMMITATING DOCTOR) “And this is erm.. Mrs Clarke.”
And this is...
How did you know that?
LAUGHS
Precognitive empathy?
I knew you’d say that. (SHE GASPS WITH PAIN,
What are they doing to you?
Watch out for the guards. Look out!
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 16
We haven’t seen any guards.
But there will be. Am I right... (FX: HE TURNS A PAPER DOCUMENT) (READS) .. “prisoner amber nine eight four nine delta?”
Pazmi. That’s what my mother called me.
Pazmi.
What are you in for? — And what have they connected you up to?
You said it was medication.
Don’t touch!
Sorry! But all the other prisoners we’ve seen are attached to an identical set-up.
Pazmi, have you always predicted the future? Or is it only Since they locked you up?
We have seers amongst our people. Wise ones who see the future the way the rest of us remember the past. Who’d have thought I’d be like them?
Your home planet being? No, let me guess. You came here from Miasimia Goria. Am I right?
I should never have left.
Didn’t you say that’s where the Rani came from?
(CONTEMPT) The Rani, ten thousand curses upon her.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 17
Not a fan then. But you still consider her your ruler? Even in absentia?
She’s a tyrant.
But she’s a prisoner here, yes? She is still here? (SUDDEN THOUGHT) You weren’t trying to spring her?
(AMUSED) No. (IMMITATING DOCTOR) “Then why are you locked up?”
Then why are you... Will you stop doing that!
But she wasn’t — not locked up, I mean. The door was open.
Ah...
(WORRIED) Maybe we shouldn’t stay.
(IMMITATING DOCTOR) “Pazmi? What happens next?”
(TO DOCTOR) Is that what you were going to say?
A vague approximation. — You’re not so good at this prediction malarkey, are you? What about the Rani? Did you find her?
The future’s just ahead, eager to happen. It’s hard to keep up. Like seeing two places at once. Now and next.
And what can you see?
(LAUGHS) Not good. Not far.
How far?
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 18
Look out!
BEAT.
Still no guards. We should go.
And if I disconnect your drip feed?
No!
Don’t touch. You’1ll hurt her!
What is this stuff, anyway?
FX: HE PULLS OUT THE TUBE. AN ALARM BEEPS.
GASPS
(SNIFFS) I know that smell — like nothing at all. Where have I
smelt that before?
Doctor, reconnect her.
FX: HE FLICKS A SWITCH. THE ALARM STOPS.
That’s enough of that. You’re better off without it.
FX: GUARDS APPROACHING DOWN CORRIDOR.
Look out! Here come those guards!
Told you.
FX: DOOR CLATTERS. GUARDS BARREL IN.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 19
Don’t move! (FX: BLIPS HIS COMMUNICATOR) Two intruders, sir. Sigma Block.
Intruders, my foot. What’s going on here? This is a surprise inspection. I demand to see the Governor!
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 20
8. INT. CORRIDORS
(DEPUTY GOVERNOR) (TANNOY — SLIGHT ECHO) Stand by. Automated feed regime commences in five params.
FX: A TRANSPORTER WHINES PAST.
SLIDE AND SLAM SHUT ECHOING UP THROUGH THE PRISON.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 21
9. INT. DEPUTY GOVERNOR’S OFFICE
FX: DOOR OPENS. DOCTOR AND CONSTANCE ENTER.
Doctor. I’m Deputy Governor Montain. Please take a seat, both of you. We have been anticipating your visit for some time.
FX: THEY SIT.
Thank you, Deputy. This is my associate, Mrs Clarke.
Hello.
Excuse the abruptness of your reception. There are protocols which all visitors to the Penitentiary must complete before disembarkation.
And our unexpected arrival breached your security?
Most certainly. There will be an enquiry.
Well, it’s good to keep you on your toes. Particularly when you’re patently so “busy”.
Always “busy”, Doctor. (FX: HE TURNS A PAGE) Now then, you were asked to attend a fiftieth anniversary review hearing about one of our inmates.
Indeed.
In fact, that request was sent out some forty-seven years ago, under the aegis of one of our previous governors.
Yes, well, I’ve been busy too.
The Doctor was concerned about your other prisoners.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 22
From what we saw, they were being subjected to a regime of unprecedented experimentation.
Merely part of our on-going sociological study into the working of the criminal mind.
Now that’s interesting - because to my untrained eye, the cells resembled a row of laboratory rats. One prisoner to a cubicle.
The woman we spoke to was in considerable distress.
Officially your visit is to discuss Prisoner indigo one eleven three six sigma.
That’s very impersonal, isn’t it? I prefer Ushas... which I grant you, she does not. She likes to be called The Rani.
Until you had her confined.
For everyone’s own good, I told you. She was a menace to the Universe. — So how is she, Deputy? Still sulking? Or making
herself useful for a change? She was always alarmingly diligent in her pursuit of creating chaos.
She was one of our model inmates.
She “was”?
Yes. I was afraid you’d say that.
In fact, we owe her a tremendous debt.
The Rani!? Oh, please. Next you’1ll be telling us she’s completely reformed. Where is she? Surely you haven’t let her go!
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB)
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Don’t fret, Doctor. I am still here.
Oh, I should have known it. Given you the run
have they?
Good morning, Governor.
Governor!
Oh, good grief.
Page 23
of the place,
You expected less? I always maximise the assets available.
Surely you know that by now?
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 24
10. INT. PAZMI’S CELL
FX: PAZMI STRUGGLES ON HER BED.
(TANNOY — SLIGHT ECHO) Stand by. Automated feed regime commences in three params.
Doctor? Why did you disconnect me? What happens next? I can’t remember. I can’t see anymore.
I just know it’s horrible!
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 25
11. INT. DEPUTY GOVERNOR’S OFFICE
I’m amazed you’re still here, Rani. Not out on the loose, causing your own inimitable brand of mayhem across the galaxy.
As opposed to your nauseating line in pompous do-gooding.
Mr Montain, I want to register my astonishment at Galactic Security’s lack of judgement over this appointment.
She is the best person for the task.
Thank you.
Dear, oh dear.
Excuse me, but what task?
(FLOUNDERING) Well, I erm...
How can anyone put a convicted criminal in charge of a prison?

Oh, she can be very persuasive. Besides, a prison would make an ideal base for whatever nefarious scheme she’s engaged on at present. When she needs another subject to experiment on — she Simply opens another cage.
But that’s unspeakable.
This is your latest devoted pupil, I take it? Another Earthling of course.
Leading Wren Clarke, ma’am.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 26
Oh, very good. The military.
Yes, ma’am.
You'd better be warned, Clarke, the Doctor’s not as reliable as he pretends. You have only to look at his record for keeping appointments to see that.
Everything in its own time.
As we all know to our cost.
Governor, the latest test feed is about to start.
I think we’ve rehearsed the procedure enough. Now the Doctor’s here, we can finally run the transfer programme in full.
Of course. (FX: HE CLICKS ON HIS COMMUNICATOR) Security. Two guards to my office please.
(TO RANI) Hang on. Have you been waiting all this time for me? Is it revenge? Is that it?
You’ve kept me waiting ninety-seven years, Doctor. There have been thirteen Prison Governors here since you had me incarcerated. Some lasted longer than others. Two actually died at that desk.
Of natural causes, I hope.
I had to make my own way somehow - slowly winning trust and benefits and ultimately authority. Less worthy contenders would have festered and lost their wits.
Worthy!
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 27
But I am nothing if not patient.
FX: DOOR OPENS. GUARDS ENTER.
Ready, Governor.
Aren’t there checks to stop this? Surely there must be checks!
It depends on who’s making the rules. — Come on, Mr Montain. Don’t just sit there!
I erm...
Wake up, man! Do something! You must have superiors at Galactic Security! Do they even know this has happened?
Don’t blame him. It’s not his fault you never answer letters. — Guards, bring these two up to Alpha level. The Pathfinder suite is already prepared.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 28
12. INT. CORRIDORS
FX: KLAXON.
(TANNOY — SLIGHT ECHO) Stand by. Automated feed regime commencing.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 29
13. INT. LIFT
FX: DOORS CLOSE.
Alpha level.
FX: LIFT WHIRRS UPWARDS. FLOORS THRUM PAST.
What now, Rani? Since you’ve elevated yourself so high, you could leave any time you like.
And waste the resources here? We’re not all fools.
Why are you blaming the Doctor? You’re a criminal. It’s not his fault you got caught and punished.
Ah, but she doesn’t have her TARDIS, you see. Poor old Rani - what rotten luck. Like losing part of yourself. I know how I'd feel.
I’ve found other compensations.
Really? Let me guess. You’ve taken up embroidery. Or playing the cello.
Doctor. Too much.
Why? Her welfare has always been close to my hearts. — I heard they had excellent facilities here. That’s why I chose it. As prisons go, this is one of the best.
And I am eternally grateful, Doctor.
Why? What does that mean?
FX: LIFT STOPS.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 30
Come and see for yourself, from the Gallery.
FX: DOORS OPEN. CONTINUES INTO:
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 31
14. INT. VIEWING GALLERY [CONTINUOUS]
MUSIC: TELLS US THAT THIS PLACE IS EXTRAORDINARY, MAJESTIC. THE
OVERLOOKS A COLLOSSAL ECHOING CHAMBER.
FX: OCCASIONAL BOLTS OF SOUND SWISH PAST FROM RANDOM
DIRECTIONS. RANI, DOCTOR, CONSTANCE AND GUARDS STEP IN.
(AWED) Oh, my goodness.
Well, I have to hand it to you, Rani. You’ve surpassed yourself this time. Huge. Magnificent. But what exactly is it for?
It’s some sort of astrolabe, isn’t it? Like a calibrated navigation device - only we’re on the inside.
Oh, very good.
It’s an armillary sphere capable of defining any given position in the cosmos.
Yes, I can see that. But why?
For an experiment I have in mind.
Constructed at tax-payers’ expenses, I assume. And what do they think they’re funding? A new exercise yard?
FX: HE’S GOING TO SHOUT Hello! ACROSS THE VAST SPACE, BUT THE
START FIRST, BOUNCING ROUND THE CHAMBER.
Doctor? What’s that?
FX: THE ECHOES FINALLY REACH THEIR ORIGINATOR.
Hello! — Oh, that’s intriguing. You’ve created a loopback timefield at the centre. It throws things back before they’ve happened.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 32
Like Pazmi echoing the future.
(SUSPICIOUS) Yes. Interesting. This is very technological for you, Rani. Have you abandoned biological research?
It will form the entrance to an artificial time portal.
Leading where? Back to your palatial bolthole on Miasimia Goria? That’s a fair stretch in spatial terms - so I assume the trip also involves time travel.
Of course. I shall return to my world as soon after my initial departure as possible.
In a bit of a state when you left, was it?
Nothing that will not be rectified.

Just saying. But you’1ll still need a quantum-sized supply of energy to power the thing. And a navigator - someone to channel it beyond the linear horizon - preferably... (REALISING) a live one. Ah...
Doctor? What’s happened?
I wish I hadn’t thought of that. A Pathfinder? Is that what you
said?
Guards — strap him into the cubicle!
FX: THE GUARDS SCUFFLE THE DOCTOR INTO A DOCKING BOOTH.
What are you doing? Leave him alone!
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 33
And put her in the holding cells.
FX: GUARDS CART CONSTANCE OFF.
(DEPARTING) Take your hands off! Let go!
(TO RANI) Mrs Clarke has done you no harm! Bring her back!
Doctor!
FX: LIFT DOORS CLOSE.
I won’t help you, Rani, if that’s what you think!
I don’t need your co-operation, Doctor. You don’t have a say in the matter.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 34
15. INT. DEPUTY GOVERNOR’S OFFICE
FX: BURST OF STATIC. BLIP.
LEADER (COMMS) Teccaurora Control from GS Transporter nine one. Request docking clearance. Code seven four. Please confirm.

Nine one, this is Deputy Governor Montain. We regret this complex is currently in lockdown. We have a code one twelve medical emergency. I repeat — code one twelve. Access is denied. Please clear the area.
FX: BURST OF STATIC. BLIP.
LEADER (COMMS )
Teccaurora, your quarantine codes have not been activated. Please confirm your status. Please confirm.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page
16. INT. HOLDING CELL
FX: GUARDS CONNECTING EQUIPMENT TO THE PRONE CONSTANCE.
(SCARED) What are you doing? Let me go!
FX: MACHINE BEEPS.
Connection fitted.
Ow! — I’m not a criminal, why are you doing this?
FX: A DRIP FEED MACHINE STARTS TO THRUM.
Feed input commencing.
FX: GUARDS LEAVING. DOOR CLOSES.
Come back! (WEAKENING) Oh... I can’t... uh... come back...
FX: DOOR OPENS.
(SOTTO) Shush... ssh... quiet.
Who... who’s that?
(SOTTO) Wait... wait. (BEAT) It’s me... Pazmi.
Please... This thing... What are they putting into me?
Hold still. Careful...
Please...
I’m trying! It’s fixed. I can’t get it off your arm!
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 36
17. INT. VIEWING GALLERY
(TANNOY) Stand by all sections. Commence stage one in thirty seconds.
Rani, I hardly dare ask where you’re getting the energy to run this experiment.
Every living mind in the universe contains a residue of temporal energy.
Miniscule amounts. Barely enough to budge a couple of atoms. The extraction process would be impossible to sustain.
This penitentiary holds nine hundred selected prisoners. But that’s more than enough!
(TANNOY) Stage one — commence.
FX: ENERGY SWISHES ROUND THE CHAMBER ABOVE THEM.
A HUM OF POWER STARTS TO BUILD.
You’re combining all the inmates’ mental capacity? All of them?
Correct.

To generate a time vector field through which you can escape? Well, apart from being obscene, it’s also insane. It won’t work. No minds can be that focussed. There’s too much else going on. Too many thoughts.
May I remind you of an experiment you once conducted during our Academy days?
(TANNOY) Stand by — stage two.
That’s going back a bit. What an egotistical bunch of know-alls we were. We thought we’d rule the universe. I hardly think any nonsense we came up with then would be relevant here.
PLANET OF THE RANI (004—AB) Page 37
You had something of the genius about you, Doctor...
Really? Oh, do you think so?
. before you went astray. (TANNOY) Stage two in thirty seconds.
Astray!
You created the Ablative...
The Ablative? Oh, yes. I remember. What a pretentious name.
A grey bacteria so basic, it verged on nothing at all. And it reduced everything it contacted to the same rudimentary level.
You know that nearly got me expelled. The Academy hushed up the ensuing chaos and destroyed all my samples. And quite right too. It was very embarrassing.
Not all the samples were destroyed.
What?
I kept one.
A sample? Of the Ablative?! Here?!
Unlike you, I have strategic facilities and deposit accounts scattered across the galaxy — simple enough for me to access.
